Description: Body sherd of Clazomenian black-figured pottery vessel, possibly a pyxis lid; interior glazed black with two added red bands; exterior, from centre: band of alternating red, white and black tongues with dots in the interstices; band of dots between narrow dilute lines; black-figure decoration consisting probably of a lion to right (part of tail, rump and back remaining, with white on body and red on under belly); on left probably part of tail of second animal.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Royal Ontario Museum, Toronto. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

For parallels regarding the shape and decoration, see Tübingen 1469 in CVA Tübingen I, pp. 33-4, firg. 9, pl. 15, no. 2-3. Cook (1952, 125, no. 20, fig. 2A) placed Tübingen 1469 in the Tübingen Group. For Hayes, date of production about 550-525 BC (Hayes 1992 p. 209 no. N28)
Bibliographic references: Hayes 1992 / Greek and Greek-Style Pottery and Plain Pottery in the Royal Ontario Museum; Excluding Black-Figure and Red-Figure Vases (p. 209, no. N28)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GH.090) (phase 3)
